explanation: The spin-statistics theorem establishes a fundamental connection in relativistic quantum field theory between a particle's intrinsic angular momentum (spin) and the statistical behavior of identical particles. Particles with integer spin must be bosons and follow Bose-Einstein statistics, while particles with half-integer spin must be fermions and follow Fermi-Dirac statistics. This theorem provides the theoretical foundation for understanding why photons can occupy the same quantum state while electrons cannot.

derivation.description: Start with relativistic quantum field theory where particles are excitations of quantum fields that transform under Lorentz symmetry.
derivation.equation: phi(x) -> U(Lambda) phi(x) U^(-1)(Lambda) = sum_mu D_(mu nu)(Lambda) phi_nu(Lambda^(-1) x)

derivation.description: Consider the exchange of two identical particles separated by a spacelike interval, ensuring causality is preserved.
Apply a Lorentz transformation that exchanges the spatial positions of the two particles while preserving their spacelike separation.
derivation.equation: Lambda: x_1 <-> x_2 text{ with } (x_1 - x_2)^2 text{ invariant}

derivation.description: The field operators at spacelike separated points must either commute (bosons) or anticommute (fermions) to preserve causality.
Under the particle exchange transformation, the field picks up a phase factor related to its Lorentz transformation properties.
derivation.equation: phi(x_1) phi(x_2) = e^(i theta) phi(x_2) phi(x_1)

derivation.description: For a field with spin s, the exchange operation corresponds to a rotation by 2π, giving a phase factor of (-1)^(2s).
Integer spin (s = 0, 1, 2, ...) gives 2s = even integer, so (-1)^(2s) = +1, requiring commuting fields (bosons).
Half-integer spin (s = 1/2, 3/2, ...) gives 2s = odd integer, so (-1)^(2s) = -1, requiring anticommuting fields (fermions).

historical_context.importance: Fundamental theorem in quantum field theory that explains the connection between particle spin and statistical behavior, forming the basis for understanding matter and force classification.
key_insights: Wolfgang Pauli first conjectured the connection in 1939
Rigorous proof developed by Pauli, Lüders, and others in the 1950s-60s
Provides theoretical foundation for the Standard Model particle classification
Explains why matter particles (fermions) obey exclusion principle while force carriers (bosons) do not
